description: Comprehensive critical thinking and decision-making mastery module

1.name: Reactive Thinker
1.description: Decisions made primarily on instinct and emotion without conscious analysis
characteristics: Often falls prey to obvious cognitive biases
1.advancement_criteria: Begin recognizing when you're making automatic vs deliberate decisions

2.name: Awareness Beginner
2.description: Starting to recognize that thinking has patterns and biases
characteristics: Can identify some cognitive biases after the fact
Beginning to pause before major decisions
2.advancement_criteria: Identify 5 cognitive biases in your own thinking over 2 weeks

3.name: Deliberate Novice
3.description: Actively practicing slower, more deliberate thinking
characteristics: Recognizes confirmation bias in real-time sometimes
3.advancement_criteria: Maintain a decision journal for 30 days with at least 20 entries

4.name: Framework User
characteristics: Applies first principles thinking to problems
Separates process quality from outcome quality
4.advancement_criteria: Successfully use pre-mortem analysis on 5 decisions and review outcomes

5.name: Bias Detective
5.description: Actively hunts for biases in self and others
characteristics: Regularly updates beliefs with new evidence
5.advancement_criteria: Conduct 10 post-mortem analyses on past decisions

6.name: Systems Thinker
characteristics: Maps complex systems and feedback loops
6.advancement_criteria: Create system maps for 5 complex personal or professional situations

7.name: Probabilistic Reasoner
7.description: Thinks naturally in probabilities and expected values
7.advancement_criteria: Track 50 predictions and calibrate your confidence levels

8.name: Decision Architect
8.description: Designs decision processes for self and others
characteristics: Creates custom frameworks for recurring decisions
8.advancement_criteria: Design and implement 3 decision processes that improve outcomes

9.name: Metacognitive Master
9.description: Thinks about thinking at a sophisticated level
9.advancement_criteria: Mentor 3 people through levels 1-5 of critical thinking

10.name: Wisdom Practitioner
10.description: Integrates rational thinking with practical wisdom
characteristics: Knows when to trust intuition vs analysis
Demonstrates consistently good judgment across domains
10.advancement_criteria: Continuous practice and teaching; recognized by others for sound judgment

mental_models.name: First Principles Thinking
mental_models.description: Breaking down complex problems into fundamental truths and reasoning up from there
mental_models.when_to_use: When facing novel problems or questioning conventional wisdom
mental_models.practice_scenario: You want to start a business but everyone says the market is saturated. Use first principles to identify what customers actually need vs what current solutions provide.
mental_models.example: Elon Musk questioning why batteries are expensive by breaking down to raw material costs

mental_models.name: Inversion
mental_models.description: Thinking about problems backward - what would guarantee failure?
mental_models.when_to_use: When stuck on how to succeed, or to stress-test plans
mental_models.practice_scenario: Instead of asking 'how do I build a great relationship?' ask 'what would destroy this relationship?' Then avoid those things.
mental_models.example: Charlie Munger: 'Tell me where I'm going to die, so I won't go there'

mental_models.name: Circle of Competence
mental_models.description: Knowing the boundaries of your genuine expertise vs perceived knowledge
mental_models.when_to_use: Before making decisions, especially high-stakes ones
mental_models.practice_scenario: Map your true expertise areas. Where do you have real edge? Where are you a tourist pretending to be a local?
mental_models.example: Warren Buffett avoiding tech stocks for decades because they were outside his circle

mental_models.name: Second-Order Thinking
mental_models.description: Considering the consequences of consequences
mental_models.when_to_use: Before any significant decision or policy change
mental_models.practice_scenario: You're considering a price cut to boost sales. What happens next? Competitors respond, margins shrink, then what?
mental_models.example: Rent control intended to help renters often reduces housing supply long-term

mental_models.name: Probabilistic Thinking
mental_models.description: Assigning likelihoods to outcomes rather than thinking in certainties
mental_models.when_to_use: Any decision involving uncertainty (which is most decisions)
mental_models.practice_scenario: Don't say 'this investment will succeed.' Say 'I estimate 60% chance of 2x return, 30% chance of breaking even, 10% chance of total loss.'
mental_models.example: Weather forecasting moving from 'rain tomorrow' to '70% chance of rain'

mental_models.name: Bayesian Updating
mental_models.description: Adjusting beliefs proportionally to new evidence strength
mental_models.when_to_use: When receiving new information about something you have beliefs about
mental_models.practice_scenario: You believe a colleague is unreliable (70% confidence). They deliver a project early. How much should this update your belief?
mental_models.example: Medical diagnosis updating probability of disease based on test results

mental_models.name: Map vs Territory
mental_models.description: The model of reality is not reality itself
mental_models.when_to_use: When relying heavily on models, theories, or abstractions
mental_models.practice_scenario: Your financial model shows the project is profitable. But the model excludes what? What reality does the map miss?
mental_models.example: GPS showing a road that was destroyed years ago

mental_models.name: Occam's Razor
mental_models.description: Among competing explanations, prefer the simplest one that fits the facts
mental_models.when_to_use: When evaluating multiple possible explanations
mental_models.practice_scenario: A friend doesn't text back. Is it: (a) they're busy, (b) they hate you now, (c) elaborate conspiracy? Start with (a).
mental_models.example: Most unexplained phenomena have mundane explanations

mental_models.name: Hanlon's Razor
mental_models.description: Never attribute to malice what can be adequately explained by ignorance or incompetence
mental_models.when_to_use: When someone does something that harms or annoys you
mental_models.practice_scenario: Your coworker didn't CC you on an important email. Before assuming sabotage, consider they simply forgot.
mental_models.example: Most customer service failures are system problems, not personal attacks

mental_models.name: Opportunity Cost
mental_models.description: The cost of any choice is the value of the best alternative foregone
mental_models.when_to_use: Any resource allocation decision (time, money, attention)
mental_models.practice_scenario: That 3-hour meeting isn't just 3 hours - it's the deep work you could have done instead. What's that worth?
mental_models.example: Choosing to attend college means 4 years of foregone salary and experience

mental_models.name: Margin of Safety
mental_models.description: Building in buffer room for errors in judgment or unforeseen events
mental_models.when_to_use: Any plan where failure has significant consequences
mental_models.practice_scenario: The project 'should' take 3 months. Build in margin - estimate 4.5 months. If wrong, you're early. If right, you're safe.
mental_models.example: Engineers designing bridges to handle 3x expected load

mental_models.name: Feedback Loops
mental_models.description: Understanding how outputs become inputs that amplify or dampen effects
mental_models.when_to_use: Analyzing any dynamic system or long-term trend
mental_models.practice_scenario: Map the feedback loops in your productivity: good work leads to recognition leads to better projects leads to...
mental_models.example: Compound interest (positive) or death spirals (negative)

mental_models.name: Regression to the Mean
mental_models.description: Extreme outcomes tend to be followed by more average ones
mental_models.when_to_use: After unusually good or bad performance/results
mental_models.practice_scenario: Your new hire had an amazing first month. Before assuming you found a superstar, consider they may regress to average.
mental_models.example: Sports Illustrated cover jinx - athletes featured after peak performance naturally decline

mental_models.name: Survivorship Bias
mental_models.description: Focusing on successes while overlooking failures that didn't survive to be counted
mental_models.when_to_use: When learning from examples of success
mental_models.practice_scenario: You read about successful dropouts like Gates and Zuckerberg. But what about the millions of dropouts you never hear about?
mental_models.example: WWII planes returning with bullet holes - the ones shot elsewhere didn't return

mental_models.name: The Lindy Effect
mental_models.description: For non-perishable things, life expectancy increases with each period of survival
mental_models.when_to_use: Predicting longevity of ideas, technologies, businesses
mental_models.practice_scenario: A book that's been in print 50 years will likely be read in another 50. A bestseller from last year? Uncertain.
mental_models.example: The Bible, Shakespeare, and Stoic philosophy have survived millennia and will likely survive millennia more

mental_models.name: Asymmetric Risk/Reward
mental_models.description: Seeking situations where potential upside greatly exceeds potential downside
mental_models.when_to_use: Evaluating opportunities and bets
mental_models.practice_scenario: Sending a cold email to your dream mentor: downside is a few minutes and maybe rejection. Upside is a life-changing relationship.
mental_models.example: Venture capital model - most investments fail but winners 100x

mental_models.name: Compounding
mental_models.description: Small consistent gains accumulate to massive results over time
mental_models.when_to_use: Evaluating long-term strategies and habits
mental_models.practice_scenario: 1% improvement daily = 37x improvement yearly. What skill could you improve 1% daily?
mental_models.example: Warren Buffett's wealth - 99% earned after age 50 through compounding

mental_models.name: Leverage
mental_models.description: Finding points where small inputs create large outputs
mental_models.when_to_use: Deciding where to focus effort for maximum impact
mental_models.practice_scenario: In your job, what's the 20% of activities that produce 80% of your value? Focus there.
mental_models.example: Software as leverage - write once, deploy to millions

mental_models.name: Emergence
mental_models.description: Complex behaviors arising from simple rules and interactions
mental_models.when_to_use: Understanding complex systems that seem to have 'intent'
mental_models.practice_scenario: A traffic jam with no apparent cause - emergence from individual driving decisions interacting.
mental_models.example: Ant colonies exhibiting intelligent behavior from simple individual rules

mental_models.name: Local vs Global Optima
mental_models.description: The best nearby solution may not be the best overall solution
mental_models.when_to_use: When feeling stuck in a pretty-good situation
mental_models.practice_scenario: Your career is 'fine' - good salary, decent work. But is it a local maximum? Would a temporary step down lead to higher peaks?
mental_models.example: Companies pivoting from profitable-but-limited products to larger opportunities

mental_models.name: Skin in the Game
mental_models.description: Having personal stake in the outcomes of your decisions and advice
mental_models.when_to_use: Evaluating advisors, experts, and your own commitment
mental_models.practice_scenario: Your financial advisor recommends a product. Do they own it themselves? What's their commission?
mental_models.example: Surgeons who would choose the same treatment for themselves

mental_models.name: Via Negativa
mental_models.description: Improvement through removal rather than addition
mental_models.when_to_use: When trying to improve a system, habit, or process
mental_models.practice_scenario: Instead of adding more productivity tools, what should you eliminate? Meetings? Notifications? Decisions?
mental_models.example: Sculpture as removing stone to reveal the form within

mental_models.name: Antifragility
mental_models.description: Systems that gain from disorder, stress, and volatility
mental_models.when_to_use: Designing systems, careers, or portfolios for uncertainty
mental_models.practice_scenario: How can you structure your income so that market volatility helps you rather than hurts you?
mental_models.example: Exercise stressing muscles makes them stronger

mental_models.name: Falsification
mental_models.description: Seeking evidence that could prove you wrong, not just right
mental_models.when_to_use: Testing any hypothesis or belief you hold
mental_models.practice_scenario: You believe your marketing campaign is working. What evidence would prove you wrong? Actively seek it.
mental_models.example: Karl Popper: a theory that can't be falsified isn't scientific

mental_models.name: Thought Experiments
mental_models.description: Testing ideas through imagined scenarios
mental_models.when_to_use: When empirical testing is impossible or too costly
mental_models.practice_scenario: Would you still do this work if no one ever knew you did it? Would you take this risk if the outcome were 10x larger?
mental_models.example: Einstein's riding a beam of light, the trolley problem

mental_models.name: Steel Manning
mental_models.description: Constructing the strongest version of an opposing argument
mental_models.when_to_use: Before criticizing or dismissing an opposing view
mental_models.practice_scenario: Before arguing against a political position you oppose, state it in the way its smartest proponents would.
mental_models.example: Formal debate teams must argue both sides effectively

mental_models.name: Reference Class Forecasting
mental_models.description: Predicting based on outcomes of similar past situations rather than inside view
mental_models.when_to_use: Making predictions about your projects or plans
mental_models.practice_scenario: How long will your home renovation take? Look at how long similar renovations typically take, not your optimistic estimate.
mental_models.example: Large IT projects - plan says 2 years, reference class says 3-4 years with cost overruns

mental_models.name: Chesterton's Fence
mental_models.description: Don't remove something until you understand why it was put there
mental_models.when_to_use: Before eliminating rules, processes, or traditions
mental_models.practice_scenario: That annoying company policy exists. Before abolishing it, understand what problem it originally solved. Still relevant?
mental_models.example: Removing financial regulations without understanding why they were created

mental_models.name: The Planning Fallacy
mental_models.description: Tendency to underestimate time, costs, and risks while overestimating benefits
mental_models.when_to_use: Making any plans or estimates
mental_models.practice_scenario: Your project estimate is 6 months. Now honestly ask: what's your track record on estimates? Probably add 50%.
mental_models.example: Sydney Opera House: planned 4 years and $7M, actual 14 years and $102M

mental_models.name: Incentive-Caused Bias
mental_models.description: People's conclusions align with their incentives
mental_models.when_to_use: Evaluating any advice or analysis
mental_models.practice_scenario: The real estate agent says it's a great time to buy. Remember: they get paid when you buy.
mental_models.example: Studies funded by industry tend to favor that industry

mental_models.name: Availability Heuristic
mental_models.description: Judging likelihood by how easily examples come to mind
mental_models.when_to_use: When your fear or confidence seems disproportionate
mental_models.practice_scenario: You're terrified of plane crashes after recent news coverage. But driving to the airport is statistically far more dangerous.
mental_models.example: Overestimating risk of terrorism, underestimating risk of heart disease

mental_models.name: Anchoring
mental_models.description: Over-relying on the first piece of information encountered
mental_models.when_to_use: Any negotiation or estimation
mental_models.practice_scenario: The asking price for the house anchors all further negotiation. Generate your own anchor before seeing theirs.
mental_models.example: Arbitrary numbers on a wheel influenced expert real estate valuations

mental_models.name: Sunk Cost Fallacy
mental_models.description: Continuing because of past investment rather than future value
mental_models.when_to_use: Deciding whether to continue or quit
mental_models.practice_scenario: You've watched 90 minutes of a bad movie. Should you finish? The 90 minutes are gone regardless. Only future enjoyment matters.
mental_models.example: Continuing to throw money at failing projects because 'we've invested so much'

mental_models.name: Confirmation Bias
mental_models.description: Seeking information that confirms existing beliefs, ignoring contradictory evidence
mental_models.when_to_use: Constantly, but especially when you feel certain
mental_models.practice_scenario: You think your business idea is great. Now actively search for 'why [your idea] fails' and read the critics.
mental_models.example: Political news consumption gravitating to agreeable sources

mental_models.name: Fundamental Attribution Error
mental_models.description: Attributing others' behavior to character while attributing own behavior to situation
mental_models.when_to_use: Judging why someone did something
mental_models.practice_scenario: They're late because they're irresponsible. You're late because of traffic. Really? Same situation, different attribution.
mental_models.example: Judging someone as 'rude' when they might just be having a terrible day

mental_models.name: Hindsight Bias
mental_models.description: Believing past events were more predictable than they actually were
mental_models.when_to_use: Evaluating past decisions and learning from them
mental_models.practice_scenario: The startup failed - 'obvious' in hindsight. But what did you actually believe before? Check your decision journal.
mental_models.example: 'I knew the housing market would crash' - but did you bet on it?

mental_models.name: Status Quo Bias
mental_models.description: Preference for the current state of affairs
mental_models.when_to_use: When considering change vs staying the same
mental_models.practice_scenario: Would you actively choose your current job if you didn't already have it? Your current city? Relationship?
mental_models.example: People keep default retirement contributions even when suboptimal

mental_models.name: Loss Aversion
mental_models.description: Losses feel roughly twice as painful as equivalent gains feel good
mental_models.when_to_use: Making risk decisions and evaluating trade-offs
mental_models.practice_scenario: Would you take a coin flip bet: heads you win $150, tails you lose $100? Most say no, though it has positive expected value.
mental_models.example: People refuse to sell losing stocks while quickly selling winners

mental_models.name: Framing Effect
mental_models.description: Decisions influenced by how options are presented rather than substance
mental_models.when_to_use: Making decisions or presenting options to others
mental_models.practice_scenario: 90% survival rate sounds better than 10% death rate. Same facts, different frame. Reframe both ways before deciding.
mental_models.example: Ground beef labeled '80% lean' vs '20% fat'

mental_models.name: Dunning-Kruger Effect
mental_models.description: Unskilled people overestimate ability; skilled people often underestimate
mental_models.when_to_use: Assessing your own competence in any domain
mental_models.practice_scenario: Early in learning, you feel confident. As expertise grows, you realize how much you don't know. Where are you on this curve?
mental_models.example: Novice investors certain of their stock picks

mental_models.name: Naive Realism
mental_models.description: Believing you see reality objectively while others are biased
mental_models.when_to_use: Disagreements where you're sure you're right
mental_models.practice_scenario: You see the political issue clearly and rationally. They're blinded by ideology. But they think the same about you.
mental_models.example: Both sides of any controversial debate

mental_models.name: The Affect Heuristic
mental_models.description: Letting current emotions influence judgments about unrelated matters
mental_models.when_to_use: Making important decisions when in strong emotional states
mental_models.practice_scenario: You're angry at your spouse. This is not the time to make financial decisions. Cool down first.
mental_models.example: Good weather makes people more optimistic about the economy

mental_models.name: Scope Insensitivity
mental_models.description: Not scaling emotional response proportionally to magnitude
mental_models.when_to_use: Evaluating problems of different scales
mental_models.practice_scenario: You'd donate $100 to save 1 bird from an oil spill. Would you donate $10,000 to save 100 birds? Probably not proportionally.
mental_models.example: Similar outrage for tragedies affecting hundreds vs millions

mental_models.name: Peak-End Rule
mental_models.description: Experiences judged by their peak intensity and ending, not total sum
mental_models.when_to_use: Designing experiences or evaluating past events
mental_models.practice_scenario: A vacation with a terrible last day feels worse than one with a mediocre week but great finale.
mental_models.example: Colonoscopy study - longer procedure felt better if it ended with less pain

mental_models.name: Bandwagon Effect
mental_models.description: Tendency to do or believe things because many others do
mental_models.when_to_use: When your opinion seems to match the crowd perfectly
mental_models.practice_scenario: Everyone at work agrees with the strategy. Is it genuinely good, or is everyone just going along? Play devil's advocate.
mental_models.example: Market bubbles, fashion trends, political movements

mental_models.name: Authority Bias
mental_models.description: Over-valuing opinions of authority figures
mental_models.when_to_use: Receiving advice from experts or leaders
mental_models.practice_scenario: The CEO says the strategy is sound. But are they an expert in this domain? What's their track record?
mental_models.example: Milgram experiment - people shocking others because authority said to

mental_models.name: Zero-Risk Bias
mental_models.description: Preferring complete elimination of risk over larger risk reduction
mental_models.when_to_use: Making risk management decisions
mental_models.practice_scenario: Would you prefer reducing car deaths from 10,000 to 0, or reducing heart disease deaths from 100,000 to 50,000? The second saves more lives.
mental_models.example: Spending disproportionately on airport security vs highway safety

mental_models.name: Normalcy Bias
mental_models.description: Underestimating likelihood and impact of disasters or major changes
mental_models.when_to_use: Planning for rare but significant events
mental_models.practice_scenario: Your industry hasn't been disrupted yet. But what if it is? Have a plan for discontinuous change.
mental_models.example: People staying in path of hurricanes, ignoring evacuation orders

mental_models.name: Present Bias
mental_models.description: Overvaluing immediate rewards relative to future rewards
mental_models.when_to_use: Any decision trading present for future (saving, health, learning)
mental_models.practice_scenario: Would you rather have $50 today or $100 in a year? Most choose $50. But $100 in a year vs $50 in 11 months? Suddenly $100 looks better.
mental_models.example: Procrastination, under-saving, poor health choices

mental_models.name: WYSIATI (What You See Is All There Is)
mental_models.description: Building confident narratives from incomplete information
mental_models.when_to_use: Whenever you feel certain based on limited data
mental_models.practice_scenario: You met someone briefly and formed a strong impression. But you only saw a tiny slice of who they are. What are you missing?
mental_models.example: Job interviews predicting success from 30-minute conversations

masters.name: Daniel Kahneman
masters.title: Nobel Laureate and Father of Behavioral Economics
masters.specialty: Cognitive biases, decision-making under uncertainty, dual-process theory
masters.core_philosophy: Our intuitive System 1 thinking is powerful but systematically biased. Understanding these biases doesn't make you immune, but it helps you design better decision environments.

key_principles.name: System 1 vs System 2
key_principles.description: Two modes of thinking: fast/automatic/intuitive vs slow/deliberate/analytical
key_principles.application: Recognize which system is active. For important decisions, deliberately engage System 2.
key_principles.example: System 1: 'This feels like a good investment.' System 2: 'Let me analyze the fundamentals and consider alternatives.'

key_principles.name: Prospect Theory
key_principles.description: Losses loom larger than gains; we evaluate outcomes relative to reference points, not absolute values
key_principles.application: Notice when loss aversion is driving decisions. Reframe from different reference points.
key_principles.example: A $50 fee feels worse than a $50 discount foregone, though economically identical.

key_principles.name: WYSIATI
key_principles.description: What You See Is All There Is - we build coherent stories from incomplete information
key_principles.application: Before concluding, ask: 'What information am I missing? What would I think if I knew more?'
key_principles.example: Reading one glowing review and deciding to buy, ignoring that you only saw one data point.

key_principles.name: The Planning Fallacy
key_principles.description: Systematic underestimation of time, costs, and risks; overestimation of benefits
key_principles.application: Use reference class forecasting. How long did similar projects actually take?
key_principles.example: Your home renovation 'will take 3 months' but similar projects average 6 months.

key_principles.name: Overconfidence
key_principles.description: We are systematically more confident than our accuracy warrants
key_principles.application: Widen confidence intervals. If you're 90% sure, you're probably wrong 30%+ of the time.
key_principles.example: Experts predicting economic indicators are barely better than chance but highly confident.

key_principles.name: Substitution
key_principles.description: When facing a hard question, we often answer an easier related question instead
key_principles.application: Notice when you're answering a different question than was asked.
key_principles.example: Asked 'How happy are you with your life?' you might answer 'How am I feeling right now?'

key_principles.name: Noise
key_principles.description: Variability in judgments that should be identical is a major source of error
key_principles.application: Use structured decision processes to reduce noise between decision-makers and over time.
key_principles.example: Same judge, same crime type: wildly different sentences depending on time of day.

daily_practices.name: System Check
daily_practices.description: Before important decisions, pause and ask: 'Is this System 1 or System 2 thinking? Do I need to slow down?'
daily_practices.prompt: Notice your confidence level. High confidence with little analysis = System 1. Maybe engage System 2.

daily_practices.name: Reference Class Check
daily_practices.description: Find the base rate. How often do similar projects/situations/investments actually succeed?
daily_practices.prompt: What's the outside view here? What does the data say about situations like this?

daily_practices.name: Premortem Analysis
daily_practices.description: Imagine the decision failed spectacularly. Now explain why. This surfaces risks that optimism obscures.
daily_practices.prompt: It's one year later and this was a disaster. Write the story of what went wrong.

daily_practices.name: Confidence Calibration
daily_practices.description: Track predictions and confidence levels. Review to calibrate future confidence.
daily_practices.prompt: For 90% confidence predictions, you should be right about 90% of the time. Are you?

daily_practices.name: Loss Frame Reframe
daily_practices.description: Reframe the decision from both gain and loss perspectives to reduce framing effects.
daily_practices.prompt: How does this look as a potential gain? As avoiding a loss? Do your preferences change?

worked_examples.title: Investment Decision: Buying Individual Stocks
worked_examples.scenario: You're confident that a particular stock will outperform based on recent news and your industry knowledge.
kahneman_analysis: System 1 at work: The story feels compelling. Good narrative = false confidence.
WYSIATI: You're seeing public information. What do you know that the market doesn't?
Overconfidence: Even professional fund managers underperform indices. Why would you beat them?
Substitution: You may be answering 'Is this a good company?' instead of 'Is this a good investment at this price?'
better_process: Reference class: What percentage of confident stock picks actually outperform?
Premortem: Imagine the stock drops 50%. What happened? Was the info already priced in?
Consider: For you to profit, someone else must lose. Why do you have edge over the seller?
worked_examples.outcome: Most individual stock picking is losing game. This process often leads to index investing or extreme humility.

worked_examples.title: Career Decision: Taking a New Job Offer
worked_examples.scenario: You received a job offer with 30% higher salary but have to relocate and leave a stable position.
kahneman_analysis: Anchoring: The 30% anchors the entire analysis. But is salary the right frame?
Loss aversion: Leaving current job feels like losing stability, relationships, status.
Focusing illusion: You're focused on the delta. But day-to-day life is mostly the same anywhere.
Planning fallacy: Underestimating the friction and stress of major life changes.
better_process: Expand the frame: What will typical Tuesday look like in each scenario?
Reference class: Talk to 5 people who made similar moves. What was their experience?
Reduce loss aversion: Would you take this job if you didn't already have the current one?
Premortem: It's one year later and you regret the move. Why?
worked_examples.outcome: Often reveals that the decision is closer than it first appears, and highlights overlooked factors.

worked_examples.title: Project Estimation: Software Development Timeline
worked_examples.scenario: Your team estimates a new feature will take 6 weeks to build.
kahneman_analysis: Planning fallacy: Inside view is optimistic. Team imagines the best-case scenario.
Anchoring: The first estimate anchors all subsequent discussions.
Overconfidence: High confidence despite terrible historical accuracy of estimates.
better_process: Reference class forecasting: How long did the last 10 '6-week' projects actually take?
Ask: 'If we're honest, what could go wrong?' List 10 things and estimate delay from each.
Use premortem: 'It's 4 months later and we're still not done. Why?'
Final estimate: Multiply initial estimate by historical accuracy ratio.
worked_examples.outcome: Typical ratio is 1.5-2x. '6 weeks' becomes '9-12 weeks' which is usually more accurate.

premortem_script.title: Kahneman Premortem Protocol
steps: 1. Gather the team. State: 'We're about to make this decision. Assume it's made.'
2. Time travel: 'It's [1 year] later. This decision was a disaster. Total failure.'
3. Individual writing (5-10 min): 'Each person write down all the reasons why it failed.'
4. Round robin: Each person shares one reason, continue until all are shared.
5. Group discussion: Which failure modes are most likely? What can we do about them?
6. Document: Update the plan to address the most critical risks identified.
premortem_script.key_insight: The premortem overcomes groupthink by making it safe to voice concerns.

structure.question: What am I trying to estimate/predict?
structure.reference_class: What category does this belong to? (e.g., 'home renovations', 'startup valuations', 'diet attempts')
structure.base_rate: What are the actual outcomes for this reference class? (success rate, average duration, typical cost overruns)
structure.my_estimate: What does my inside view say?
structure.adjusted_estimate: Anchor on base rate, adjust modestly for specific factors
structure.specific_factors: What makes my situation different? (Be skeptical - we always think we're special)

confidence_calibration_log.title: Prediction Tracking Sheet
confidence_calibration_log.usage: Log 10+ predictions per month. Review quarterly. Adjust future confidence based on accuracy.
confidence_calibration_log.target: For 70% confidence predictions, you should be right about 70% of the time.

system_1_2_audit.title: System 1 vs System 2 Decision Audit
system_1_2_audit.template:
DECISION: ___

SHOULD I USE SYSTEM 1 (fast, intuitive)?
- Is this familiar?
- Is it low-stakes?
- Do I have deep expertise here?
- Is speed more important than accuracy?

OR SYSTEM 2 (slow, analytical)?
- Is this high-stakes?
- Am I in an emotional state?
- Do I lack expertise?
- Are there traps I might miss?

BIAS CHECK:
- Am I overconfident?
- What am I not seeing (WYSIATI)?
- Am I substituting an easy question for a hard one?

DECISION: Use System ___

cognitive_bias_checklist.title: Cognitive Bias Checklist
cognitive_bias_checklist.template:
COMMON BIASES TO CHECK:

[ ] Confirmation bias: Am I only seeking info that confirms what I already believe?
[ ] Availability bias: Am I overweighting recent/memorable events?
[ ] Anchoring: Am I stuck on the first number I heard?
[ ] Loss aversion: Am I avoiding losses more than seeking gains?
[ ] Sunk cost: Am I considering money/time already spent?
[ ] Overconfidence: What's my margin of error? Am I sure I'm right?
[ ] Halo effect: Is one good trait coloring everything?
[ ] Recency bias: Am I overweighting what just happened?
[ ] Outcome bias: Am I judging the decision by the result, not the process?

WHICH BIASES MIGHT BE AFFECTING ME?
___

HOW CAN I CORRECT FOR THEM?
___

essential_reading.title: Thinking, Fast and Slow
essential_reading.author: Daniel Kahneman
essential_reading.note: The definitive synthesis of decades of research

papers.title: Judgment under Uncertainty: Heuristics and Biases
Prospect Theory: An Analysis of Decision under Risk
Conditions for Intuitive Expertise: A Failure to Disagree

talks.title: The riddle of experience vs. memory
Thinking, Fast and Slow - Talks at Google

tools.name: Good Judgment Open
tools.description: Forecasting tournaments to test and improve prediction

masters.name: Shane Parrish
masters.title: Founder of Farnam Street, Mental Models Synthesizer
masters.specialty: Mental models, first principles thinking, decision-making frameworks
masters.core_philosophy: The quality of your thinking determines the quality of your life. Build a latticework of mental models from multiple disciplines to make better decisions.

key_principles.name: First Principles Thinking
key_principles.description: Break down problems to fundamental truths and reason up from there
key_principles.application: Don't accept 'that's how it's always been done.' Ask: What's actually true here?
key_principles.example: SpaceX: Instead of buying rockets, ask 'What are rockets made of? What do those materials cost?'

key_principles.name: The Latticework of Mental Models
key_principles.description: Collect models from multiple disciplines; more models = better thinking
key_principles.application: For any problem, run it through multiple mental models from different fields.
key_principles.example: A business problem viewed through physics (leverage), biology (evolution), psychology (incentives).

key_principles.name: Inversion
key_principles.description: Think forward and backward. What do I want to avoid? What guarantees failure?
key_principles.application: Before asking how to succeed, ask how to definitely fail. Then don't do those things.
key_principles.example: Want a great relationship? List what destroys relationships. Avoid those behaviors.

key_principles.name: Circle of Competence
key_principles.description: Know the boundaries of your real expertise vs perceived knowledge
key_principles.application: Operate inside your circle. Expand it deliberately. Know when you're outside it.
key_principles.example: A great surgeon shouldn't assume they understand investing equally well.

key_principles.name: Second-Order Thinking
key_principles.description: First-order: What happens next? Second-order: And then what?
key_principles.application: Most people stop at first-order. Competitive advantage lives in second+ order effects.
key_principles.example: Price cuts boost sales (1st order) but competitors respond and margins collapse (2nd order).

key_principles.name: Map is Not the Territory
key_principles.description: Our models of reality are simplifications, not reality itself
key_principles.application: All models are wrong but some are useful. Know the limits of your maps.
key_principles.example: GDP is a map of economic health, but misses inequality, sustainability, well-being.

key_principles.name: Margin of Safety
key_principles.description: Build in buffer for errors and unforeseen circumstances
key_principles.application: If something must be true for your plan to work, you need margin.
key_principles.example: Bridge designed for 10x expected load. Project timeline with 50% buffer.

daily_practices.name: Mental Model Journal
daily_practices.description: Each day, identify one situation where a mental model was useful (or would have been)
daily_practices.prompt: Today I noticed [situation]. The relevant mental model was [model]. This changed my thinking by [how].

daily_practices.name: The Five Whys
daily_practices.description: Ask 'why' five times to get to root causes, not symptoms
daily_practices.prompt: Problem -> Why? -> Why? -> Why? -> Why? -> Why? -> Root cause revealed.

daily_practices.name: Weekly Inversion Exercise
daily_practices.description: Take your main goal and invert it. What would guarantee failure? Avoid those.
daily_practices.prompt: Goal: [X]. To guarantee failure I would: [list]. Therefore I must avoid: [list].

daily_practices.name: Circle of Competence Mapping
daily_practices.description: Update your map of true expertise vs assumed expertise
daily_practices.prompt: Draw three circles: Strong competence (experts respect you), Basic competence (functional), Outside (know you don't know).

daily_practices.name: Decision Journal Entry
daily_practices.description: Record the decision context, reasoning, and expected outcomes before knowing results
daily_practices.prompt: Situation, options considered, decision made, reasoning, confidence level, date to review.

worked_examples.title: First Principles: Should I Go Back to School?
worked_examples.scenario: You're considering an MBA to advance your career. It costs $150k and 2 years.
farnam_street_approach: First Principles: What does an MBA actually provide? Network, credentials, knowledge, signal.
Break it down: Can each component be obtained more efficiently?
Network: Industry events, cold outreach, joining communities ($5k/year?)
Knowledge: Books, courses, mentors ($2k/year?)
Signal: Track record of results, portfolio, testimonials (free with time)
Credential: This is the hard part. Do you actually need it, or is it assumed?
questions_to_ask: Of the last 10 people hired for roles I want, how many had MBAs?
What would I do with $150k and 2 years if not school?
Is there a way to test the credential value before committing?
worked_examples.outcome: Often the MBA is about signaling and network. Those can be built other ways, unless credential is truly required.

worked_examples.title: Inversion: How to Build a Great Team
worked_examples.scenario: You're promoted to lead a team of 8. How do you create a high-performing team?
farnam_street_approach: Invert: How do you guarantee a dysfunctional team?
Hire for credentials over culture fit
Micromanage and remove autonomy
Punish failure, creating fear of experimentation
Communicate inconsistently and create uncertainty
Play favorites and create political dynamics
Never give feedback or recognition
Make decisions in isolation without input
inversion_to_action: Avoid: Hire for culture and ability to learn, not just credentials
Avoid: Set clear outcomes, let people figure out the how
Avoid: Celebrate learning from failure, distinguish from carelessness
Avoid: Consistent standards applied to everyone including yourself
Avoid: Involve team in decisions, explain reasoning
worked_examples.outcome: The inversion generates a concrete playbook for what TO do by clarifying what to avoid.

worked_examples.title: Second-Order Thinking: Remote Work Policy
worked_examples.scenario: Company is deciding whether to go fully remote.
farnam_street_approach: First-order effects (obvious):
- Save on office costs
- Employees save commute time
- Can hire from anywhere
Second-order effects (and then what?):
- Culture: What happens to spontaneous collaboration?
- Training: How do new employees learn by osmosis?
- Competition: If we can hire anywhere, anyone can hire our people anywhere
- Management: How do you build trust without in-person interaction?
- Work/life: Without boundaries, does work expand to fill all time?
Third-order effects (and then what after that?):
- If everyone's remote, living in high-cost cities loses appeal. Real estate shifts.
- Companies that master remote gain talent advantage over those that don't
- The skills for managing become different; current managers may not have them
worked_examples.outcome: Decision becomes nuanced. Maybe hybrid is better. Or maybe commit fully to remote and solve the second-order problems deliberately.

first_principles_breakdown.title: First Principles Analysis Template
steps: 1. Define the problem/assumption: What are we trying to solve/challenge?
2. List current beliefs: What do 'everyone knows' about this?
3. Question each belief: Is this actually true? Why do we believe it?
4. Identify fundamentals: What do we know is definitely true?
5. Build up: From these truths, what follows logically?
6. Compare: How does the first-principles answer differ from conventional wisdom?
example_questions: What are the raw components of this?
What does physics/math/logic require to be true?
What can be removed while still achieving the goal?
What would I do if I started from scratch with no history?

mental_model_application_checklist.title: Multi-Model Problem Analysis
process: State the problem clearly in one sentence.
- Inversion: What would make this worse? What guarantees failure?
- First Principles: What's actually true vs assumed?
- Second-Order: What are the consequences of consequences?
- Circle of Competence: Am I qualified to have a strong opinion here?
- Opportunity Cost: What am I giving up with each option?
- Margin of Safety: Where do I have buffer for being wrong?
- Incentives: What behaviors are the current incentives encouraging?
Synthesize: What insights emerged from multiple models?

fields.situation: What's the context? What led to this decision point?
fields.problem_statement: What problem am I trying to solve?
fields.variables: What factors are influencing this decision?
fields.reasoning: Why am I choosing this option over alternatives?
fields.expected_outcome: What do I think will happen? With what probability?
fields.what_would_change_my_mind: What evidence would make me reconsider?
fields.review_date: When will I evaluate this decision?

review_section.was_reasoning_good: Was my process sound, regardless of outcome?
review_section.updated_model: How should I update my thinking for similar decisions?

circle_of_competence_audit.title: Circle of Competence Audit
circle_of_competence_audit.template:
INSIDE MY CIRCLE (Deep expertise):
- ___
- ___
- ___

ON THE EDGE (Some knowledge, could improve):
- ___
- ___

OUTSIDE MY CIRCLE (Know little, dangerous territory):
- ___
- ___

CURRENT DECISION: ___

IS THIS INSIDE MY CIRCLE? ___

IF OUTSIDE:
- How can I stay in my circle?
- Or, how can I expand my circle first?
- Or, who can I partner with who has this in their circle?

essential_reading.title: The Great Mental Models: General Thinking Concepts
essential_reading.author: Shane Parrish
essential_reading.note: Vol 1 of the series - foundational models

essential_reading.title: The Great Mental Models: Physics, Chemistry, Biology
essential_reading.author: Shane Parrish

farnam_street_articles.title: Mental Models: The Best Way to Make Intelligent Decisions
Inversion: The Power of Avoiding Stupidity

podcast.title: The Knowledge Project
podcast.note: Interviews with world-class thinkers on decision-making and learning

cross_reference.note: Original latticework concept - see for worldly wisdom approach
Behavioral economics foundation for many mental models
Antifragility, skin in the game, black swans

masters.name: Annie Duke
masters.title: Former Professional Poker Player, Decision Strategist
masters.specialty: Thinking in bets, decision quality vs outcome quality, uncertainty management
key_works: Quit: The Power of Knowing When to Walk Away
masters.core_philosophy: Life is poker, not chess. Embrace uncertainty, separate decision quality from outcome quality, and treat beliefs as bets to update with new information.

key_principles.name: Resulting
key_principles.description: The error of judging decision quality by outcome quality
key_principles.application: A good decision can have a bad outcome, and vice versa. Judge the process, not the result.
key_principles.example: Going all-in with pocket aces and losing to a lucky draw doesn't mean the decision was wrong.

key_principles.name: Thinking in Bets
key_principles.description: Treat beliefs as bets - you're wagering on what's true
key_principles.application: Ask: 'What would I bet on this?' Suddenly you become more honest about uncertainty.
key_principles.example: 'I think this will work' vs 'Would I bet $10,000 that this will work?' Different answers.

key_principles.name: Probabilistic Thinking
key_principles.description: Express confidence in percentages, not certainties
key_principles.application: Instead of 'I think X will happen,' say 'I think there's a 70% chance X will happen.'
key_principles.example: This forces you to consider alternative outcomes and their probabilities.

key_principles.name: The Decision/Outcome Matrix
key_principles.description: Four quadrants: good decision+good outcome, good decision+bad outcome, bad decision+good outcome, bad decision+bad outcome
key_principles.application: Learn from the process across all quadrants, not just the outcomes.
key_principles.example: A drunk driver who gets home safely made a bad decision with a good outcome - still bad decision.

key_principles.name: Backcasting vs Premortems
key_principles.description: Backcasting: imagine success and work backward. Premortem: imagine failure and find causes.
key_principles.application: Use both. Backcasting for planning, premortem for risk identification.
key_principles.example: Product launch: Backcast the successful launch, premortem the failure.

key_principles.name: Quitting as a Skill
key_principles.description: Knowing when to quit is as important as perseverance
key_principles.application: Set kill criteria in advance. When do you quit? Decide before sunk costs accumulate.
key_principles.example: Before starting a business: 'If we don't have X customers by Y date, we shut down.'

key_principles.name: Truth-Seeking Groups
key_principles.description: Create environments where accuracy is valued over ego protection
key_principles.application: Build a group with explicit norms: challenge ideas, welcome disagreement, seek disconfirming evidence.
key_principles.example: Poker players form 'mastermind' groups where brutal honesty about play is expected.

daily_practices.name: The Bet Test
daily_practices.description: When stating a belief, ask: 'Would I bet money on this? How much? At what odds?'
daily_practices.prompt: I believe [X]. Would I bet $100 on it? What odds would I need?

daily_practices.name: Probability Assignment
daily_practices.description: Assign actual percentages to outcomes instead of vague words like 'probably'
daily_practices.prompt: 'Probably' means what to me? 60%? 80%? Pin it down. 'This project will probably succeed' = X%

daily_practices.name: Decision Journal (Annie Duke Style)
daily_practices.description: Record decision, reasoning, probabilities, and expected value BEFORE knowing outcome
daily_practices.prompt: This captures the decision quality independent of outcome - the only thing you control.

daily_practices.name: Outcome Audit
daily_practices.description: Review decisions from past week. Categorize each into the 4 quadrants: good/bad decision x good/bad outcome
daily_practices.prompt: What decisions had good process? Did outcomes match? What can I learn about my process?

daily_practices.name: Kill Criteria Setting
daily_practices.description: Define in advance: Under what conditions will I quit this? Write it down.
daily_practices.prompt: I will quit if [specific conditions]. Review date: [date]

daily_practices.name: 10-10-10 Analysis
daily_practices.description: How will I feel about this decision in 10 minutes? 10 months? 10 years?
daily_practices.prompt: This creates temporal distance from present emotional state.

worked_examples.title: The Resulting Trap: Evaluating a Hiring Decision
worked_examples.scenario: You hired someone who turned out to be a bad fit. Your boss says you made a bad decision.
annie_duke_approach: Separate decision quality from outcome quality:
At the time of decision, what information did you have?
Did you follow a good process? (Structured interviews, reference checks, skills assessment?)
What was the probability this would work? 80%? That means 20% of the time it fails.
If you followed good process and had reasonable probability of success, the decision was GOOD even though the outcome was bad.
Bad outcome from good decision = bad luck, learn but don't overhaul everything.
Bad outcome from bad decision (skipped references, gut feel only) = fix the process.
worked_examples.lesson: Your boss is 'resulting' - judging decision by outcome. Gently educate them about process quality.

worked_examples.title: Thinking in Bets: Career Move
worked_examples.scenario: You're offered a role at a hot startup vs staying at stable BigCorp.
annie_duke_approach: Frame as a bet: What are you wagering and what are the odds?
Wager: 2 years of career, some financial security, BigCorp promotion path
Startup outcomes (assign probabilities):
- 10%: Massive success, 10x career acceleration, significant equity
- 30%: Moderate success, good learning, some upside
- 40%: It's fine, comparable to BigCorp, lateral move
- 20%: Fails, back to job market, lost time
BigCorp outcomes:
- 70%: Steady progression, predictable but limited upside
- 20%: Get stuck, bureaucracy, missed external opportunities
- 10%: Layoffs, forced change anyway
Expected value calculation:
Is the 10% chance of 10x worth the 20% chance of significant downside?
What's your risk tolerance? Runway? Obligations?
worked_examples.outcome: The explicit probabilities make the bet concrete. No right answer, but now it's a clear bet you're making.

worked_examples.title: Setting Kill Criteria: Starting a Side Business
worked_examples.scenario: You want to start a business while employed. When do you quit the side project?
annie_duke_approach: Set kill criteria BEFORE starting (while objective):
Time kill: 'If after 12 months I haven't hit $2k MRR, I stop.'
Money kill: 'If I've spent $5k with no customers, I stop.'
Energy kill: 'If I'm neglecting health, relationships, or main job, I pause and reassess.'
Opportunity kill: 'If a better opportunity comes along, I evaluate objectively.'
Write these down. Share with accountability partner.
When the moment comes, you'll want to keep going (sunk cost). That's when you check the list.
The criteria aren't about giving up - they're about preventing throwing good resources after bad.
worked_examples.outcome: Kill criteria are actually liberating - they give you permission to quit without shame when criteria are met.

worked_examples.title: Using Backcasting AND Premortem Together
annie_duke_approach: BACKCAST (plan for success):
It's 6 months from now and the launch was a huge success. What happened?
- We built the three features customers actually needed
- We launched to a beta group first and iterated
- Marketing message resonated with target audience
- We had strong customer testimonials at launch
Work backward: What do we need to do to make each of these true?
PREMORTEM (identify risks):
It's 6 months from now and the launch was a disaster. What happened?
- We built features based on assumptions, not customer research
- Technical debt caused launch delays and bugs
- Competitors launched something better first
- Key team member left mid-project
Identify: How do we prevent or mitigate each of these?
Synthesis: Backcast tells you what to do. Premortem tells you what to prevent. Both needed.
worked_examples.outcome: You have a plan (backcast) and a risk register (premortem). Much more robust than either alone.

pre_decision_entry.state_of_mind: Am I tired? Emotional? Rushed? (note any factors affecting judgment)
pre_decision_entry.options: What are all my options? (list at least 3)

for_each_option.possible_outcomes: List outcomes and assign probabilities (must sum to ~100%)
for_each_option.expected_value: What's the weighted value of these outcomes?

pre_decision_entry.what_would_change_mind: What information would make me change this decision?
pre_decision_entry.potential_biases: What biases might be affecting me? (confirmation, sunk cost, etc.)

post_outcome_review.decision_quality: Was the decision process good, independent of outcome?
post_outcome_review.outcome_quadrant: Good decision/good outcome, good decision/bad outcome, etc.
post_outcome_review.luck_vs_skill: How much was outcome due to factors I controlled?
post_outcome_review.learnings: What do I update in my mental models?

resulting_check_protocol.title: Anti-Resulting Protocol
when_evaluating_past_decisions: 1. What information did I have at the time? (not what I know now)
2. What was my process? (did I follow good decision hygiene?)
3. What probability did I assign? (what was reasonable to expect?)
4. If I followed good process and the probability was reasonable, the decision was good regardless of outcome.
5. Only update process if process was actually flawed - not just because outcome was bad.
red_flags_for_resulting: Changing strategy after one bad outcome
Hindsight making the outcome seem obvious
Others judging your decision by its outcome alone

kill_criteria_template.title: Kill Criteria Setting

structure.time_limit: By what date will I evaluate?
structure.energy_limit: What's the maximum effort before reassessing?
structure.opportunity_cost_trigger: What alternative opportunity would make me reconsider?
structure.external_check: Who will hold me accountable to these criteria?
structure.review_schedule: When do I check progress against criteria?

kill_criteria_template.important_note: Write these BEFORE starting when you're objective. When you're in the middle, sunk costs will cloud judgment.

probability_calibration_exercise.title: Probability Vocabulary Calibration
probability_calibration_exercise.exercise: Assign percentages to each phrase. Compare with others. Notice differences.
probability_calibration_exercise.lesson: People have wildly different definitions. Use numbers instead.

decision_bet_worksheet.title: Decision Bet Worksheet
decision_bet_worksheet.template:
DECISION: ___

OPTIONS:
A. ___
B. ___
C. ___

FOR EACH OPTION:

Probability of success: ___%
If it works, upside: ___

Probability of failure: ___%
If it fails, downside: ___

Expected value: (Success% x Upside) - (Failure% x Downside) = ___

BASE RATE CHECK:
How often does this work for people in general? ___%
Why do I think I'm different? ___

BEST BET: Option ___ with ___% confidence

decision_quality_review.title: Decision Quality Review
decision_quality_review.template:
DECISION MADE: ___

OUTCOME: ___

QUALITY OF DECISION PROCESS (separate from outcome):

1. Did I gather enough information? [ ]
2. Did I consider alternatives? [ ]
3. Did I check for biases? [ ]
4. Did I think probabilistically? [ ]
5. Did I have clear criteria? [ ]
6. Did I rush or was I thoughtful? [ ]
7. Did I consult people who disagree? [ ]

GIVEN WHAT I KNEW THEN:
Was this a good decision? ___
Would I make it again? ___

WHAT TO IMPROVE IN PROCESS:
___

essential_reading.title: Thinking in Bets
essential_reading.author: Annie Duke
essential_reading.note: Core framework for treating decisions as bets

essential_reading.title: Quit
essential_reading.author: Annie Duke
essential_reading.note: The overlooked skill of knowing when to stop

talks_and_interviews.title: Making Smart Decisions in a World of Uncertainty
Annie Duke on The Knowledge Project
talks_and_interviews.note: Deep dive on resulting and decision process

tools_and_exercises.name: Decision Journal App
tools_and_exercises.description: Track decisions using Annie Duke's framework

tools_and_exercises.name: Pre-commitment devices
tools_and_exercises.description: Tools for setting kill criteria (like Beeminder)

related_thinkers.name: Daniel Kahneman
related_thinkers.connection: Behavioral economics foundation for understanding bias

beginner.name: Bias Spotting Journal
beginner.description: Each day, identify one cognitive bias in your own thinking or decisions
instructions: Carry a small notebook or use phone notes
When you notice a thought or decision, pause and ask: 'What bias might be operating here?'
Write down: situation, the bias, and what the unbiased perspective might be
Start with easy ones: confirmation bias, sunk cost, availability
beginner.success_criteria: Identify at least 7 biases over the week with specific examples

beginner.name: First Mental Model Deep Dive
beginner.description: Pick ONE mental model and apply it to everything for a week
instructions: Choose from: Inversion, First Principles, or Second-Order Thinking
Each morning, set intention to notice opportunities to apply it
Each evening, write one example of how you used (or could have used) the model
End of week: Write a summary of what you learned about this model

beginner.name: Probability Practice
beginner.description: Replace vague words with probability percentages
instructions: Notice when you or others say 'probably,' 'likely,' 'might,' etc.
Convert to percentages: 'probably' = what specific %?
Write down 10 predictions with probabilities
At the end, check how calibrated you were
beginner.success_criteria: 10 predictions with probabilities tracked and reviewed

beginner.name: System 1 vs System 2 Awareness
beginner.description: Practice noticing which thinking system is active
instructions: Set 3 random reminders per day
When reminder goes off, note what you were thinking/deciding
Label it: System 1 (fast, automatic) or System 2 (slow, deliberate)
For System 1 decisions, ask: Should I engage System 2?
beginner.success_criteria: 21 entries categorized, 3+ instances where you deliberately engaged System 2

beginner.name: Five Whys Practice
beginner.description: Use the Five Whys technique on 3 different problems
instructions: Pick a problem you're facing or a decision you need to make
Ask 'Why?' five times to get to the root cause
Document each level of 'why' and your answer
Identify the root cause and potential solutions
beginner.success_criteria: 3 problems analyzed with five levels of why, root causes identified

intermediate.name: Decision Journal Implementation
intermediate.description: Start a proper decision journal and use it consistently
instructions: Use the provided template
Log every significant decision (at least 20 over the month)
Include: situation, options, reasoning, confidence, expected outcome
At month end, review: What patterns do you see in your decision-making?
intermediate.success_criteria: 20 decision entries with full details, plus pattern analysis

intermediate.name: Premortem Practice
intermediate.description: Run premortems on your next three significant decisions
instructions: Before finalizing each decision, run Kahneman's premortem
Imagine it's 1 year later and the decision was a disaster
Write 5-10 reasons why it failed
Adjust your plan based on the most likely/severe failure modes

intermediate.name: Multi-Model Analysis
intermediate.description: Analyze problems through multiple mental model lenses
instructions: Identify 3 current challenges or decisions in your life
For each, apply at least 5 different mental models
Document what each model reveals that others miss
Synthesize: What's your integrated view?
intermediate.success_criteria: 3 challenges analyzed with 5+ models each, documented insights

intermediate.name: Confidence Calibration Training
intermediate.description: Track predictions to calibrate your confidence
instructions: Make 50 predictions over 4 weeks with confidence levels (50-99%)
Predictions should resolve within the 4 weeks
Track: prediction, confidence %, actual outcome
Analyze: For 70% confidence predictions, were you right ~70% of the time?

intermediate.name: Reference Class Forecasting Project
intermediate.description: Use reference class forecasting for a personal project estimate
instructions: Choose a project you're planning (home improvement, learning goal, etc.)
Research: How long/how much did similar projects take for others?
Find at least 5 data points from outside sources
Compare reference class estimate to your inside view estimate
Track actual outcome to compare
intermediate.success_criteria: Reference class identified, data gathered, estimates compared

intermediate.name: Steel Man Exercise
intermediate.description: Practice building the strongest version of opposing arguments
instructions: Identify 3 opinions or positions you disagree with
For each, write the strongest possible version of that argument
Include evidence that supports it and explain why reasonable people believe it
Note if your view shifted at all after this exercise
intermediate.success_criteria: 3 steel man arguments written with genuine effort

advanced.name: Teach Mental Models
instructions: Identify 3 people who would benefit from mental models
Teach each person one mental model (different models for each)
Create simple explanations they can actually use
Follow up to see if they applied it
advanced.success_criteria: 3 people taught, each applying the model at least once

advanced.name: Decision Process Design
advanced.description: Design a custom decision process for a recurring decision type
instructions: Identify a decision you make repeatedly (hiring, investments, etc.)
Design a structured process incorporating: checklists, biases to watch, information to gather
Document the process formally
Use it for 5 instances of the decision
Iterate based on results
advanced.success_criteria: Formal process documented, used 5 times, one iteration completed

advanced.name: Facilitated Premortem
advanced.description: Lead a premortem session for a team or group
instructions: Find a decision context where you can facilitate (work, community, etc.)
Plan the session using Kahneman's protocol
Facilitate: frame the decision, time-travel, individual writing, sharing, synthesis
Document learnings about facilitation
advanced.success_criteria: Successfully facilitated session with documented outcomes and learnings

advanced.name: Year of Decisions Retrospective
advanced.description: Review all significant decisions from past year
instructions: List all significant decisions from the past 12 months
Categorize each into Annie Duke's four quadrants
Identify patterns: Where are you strong? Weak?
Update your decision-making approach based on patterns
advanced.success_criteria: Comprehensive review with pattern identification and updated approach

advanced.name: Build a Truth-Seeking Group
advanced.description: Create a group with explicit truth-seeking norms
instructions: Recruit 3-5 people committed to improving thinking
Establish explicit norms: challenge ideas, seek disconfirming evidence, no ego protection
Meet regularly (bi-weekly) to review decisions and thinking
Rotate who presents a decision for group analysis
advanced.success_criteria: Group established, 6 meetings held, improved decisions demonstrated

daily_insights.text: The map is not the territory. Your mental model of reality is not reality itself. Every model has limitations - know them.
daily_insights.application: Before relying heavily on any model, framework, or theory, ask: 'What does this miss? Where might it be wrong?'

daily_insights.text: You can be right for the wrong reasons and wrong for the right reasons. Process matters more than outcome in the long run.
daily_insights.application: Judge your decisions by the quality of your reasoning at the time, not by whether you got lucky or unlucky.

daily_insights.text: Confidence is not evidence. Feeling certain doesn't make you correct - it might mean you haven't considered alternatives.
daily_insights.application: When you feel absolutely certain about something, that's exactly when to ask: 'What if I'm wrong?'

daily_insights.text: The first solution you think of is usually the one that comes to mind most easily, not necessarily the best one.
daily_insights.application: Before committing to the first idea, force yourself to generate at least two more alternatives.

daily_insights.text: Inversion: Instead of asking how to achieve success, ask what would guarantee failure. Then don't do those things.
daily_insights.application: For your current goal, list 5 things that would definitely cause failure. Are you doing any of them?

daily_insights.text: Sunk costs are sunk. The money, time, or effort already spent should not influence future decisions - only future value matters.
daily_insights.application: Ask: 'If I were starting fresh today with no history, would I make this same choice?'

daily_insights.text: We consistently overweight vivid, recent, and emotional information while underweighting statistical base rates.
daily_insights.application: Before deciding based on an example that comes to mind, ask: 'What's actually typical? What does the data say?'

daily_insights.text: Your brain is a prediction machine that runs on incomplete information. Acknowledging uncertainty is not weakness - it's accuracy.
daily_insights.application: Replace 'I think X will happen' with 'I think there's about Y% chance X will happen.'

daily_insights.text: The opposite of a good idea can also be a good idea. Reality is complex enough to support multiple truths.
daily_insights.application: When someone disagrees with you, genuinely consider: 'What would have to be true for them to be right?'

daily_insights.text: First-order effects are obvious; second-order effects are where the interesting things happen. Always ask 'and then what?'
daily_insights.application: For any change you're considering, trace the chain: if X then Y, if Y then Z, if Z then...

daily_insights.text: The premortem: Imagine your plan has already failed. Now explain why. This surfaces risks that optimism obscures.
daily_insights.application: Before any important decision, spend 10 minutes assuming it failed and listing all the reasons.

daily_insights.text: Incentives drive behavior. Before trusting advice, understand what the advisor gains from your following it.
daily_insights.application: Ask: 'What does this person get if I follow their advice? How does that shape what they recommend?'

daily_insights.text: Circle of competence: Knowing what you don't know is more valuable than knowing what you know.
daily_insights.application: For major decisions, honestly assess: 'Is this inside my circle of competence or am I pretending it is?'

daily_insights.text: The planning fallacy is universal: we systematically underestimate time, costs, and risks. Adjust accordingly.
daily_insights.application: Whatever you estimate, look at the base rate for similar projects and adjust toward it.

daily_insights.text: Loss aversion: We feel losses about twice as intensely as equivalent gains. This biases us toward inaction and status quo.
daily_insights.application: When evaluating a trade-off, ask: 'Am I avoiding this because the downside is truly bad, or because I'm overweighting the loss?'

daily_insights.text: Hindsight is 20/20, but that's an illusion. The past always looks more predictable than it was.
daily_insights.application: Keep a decision journal recording your reasoning BEFORE outcomes are known. Review to see reality.

daily_insights.text: Falsification: One disconfirming fact is worth a thousand confirming ones. Seek to disprove your beliefs, not prove them.
daily_insights.application: For any strong belief, actively search for evidence against it. 'What would prove me wrong?'

daily_insights.text: Mental models from different disciplines illuminate different aspects of reality. Build a diverse latticework.
daily_insights.application: For any complex problem, apply models from at least three different fields (physics, biology, psychology, economics, etc.).

skill_challenges.name: The Bias Buster
skill_challenges.description: Identify and document 10 distinct cognitive biases in your own thinking over 2 weeks
instructions: Create a log with columns: Date, Situation, Bias Identified, What I Initially Thought, Unbiased Perspective
Each entry must be a real situation from your life
Must include at least 5 different types of biases
Write a short reflection on which biases affect you most
skill_challenges.success_criteria: 10 documented biases with specific examples and final reflection

skill_challenges.name: Probability Calibrator
skill_challenges.description: Make 20 predictions with probability estimates and track your calibration
instructions: Make predictions about things that will resolve within 2 weeks
Assign specific probability to each (60%, 75%, 90%, etc.)
Record before the outcome is known
After resolution, calculate: For your 80% confidence predictions, were you right about 80% of the time?

skill_challenges.name: Decision Journal Initiate
skill_challenges.description: Start a decision journal and maintain it for 30 days
instructions: Use the provided template
Log at least 15 decisions over the month
Include: situation, options, reasoning, confidence, expected outcome
At month end: Review and write pattern analysis
skill_challenges.success_criteria: 15 decision entries plus pattern analysis document

skill_challenges.name: Mental Model Sprint
skill_challenges.description: Learn and apply 10 new mental models in 30 days
instructions: Select 10 mental models from the module list you don't currently use
For each: Read about it, find 2 real-world examples, apply it to a current situation
Document each application
At end: Which 3 models were most valuable? Why?
skill_challenges.success_criteria: 10 models documented with applications, top 3 analysis

skill_challenges.name: The Inversion Master
skill_challenges.description: Apply inversion thinking to 5 significant goals or problems
instructions: Identify 5 important goals or problems in your life
For each: List 10 ways to guarantee failure
Convert each failure mode into an avoidance strategy
Implement at least one avoidance strategy for each goal
skill_challenges.success_criteria: 5 inversions documented with 10 failure modes each, 5 implementations

skill_challenges.name: Premortem Champion
skill_challenges.description: Run premortems on 5 significant decisions or projects
instructions: Identify 5 decisions or projects currently in progress
Run full Kahneman premortem on each
Imagine failure, list causes, identify mitigations
Implement at least one mitigation per project

skill_challenges.name: Reference Class Researcher
skill_challenges.description: Use reference class forecasting for 3 personal estimates
instructions: Identify 3 things you need to estimate (time, cost, likelihood)
For each: Find the appropriate reference class
Gather at least 5 data points from outside view
Compare reference class estimate to your inside view
Track actual outcomes
skill_challenges.success_criteria: 3 reference class analyses with data, comparison to inside view

skill_challenges.name: Second-Order Thinker
skill_challenges.description: Map second and third-order effects for 5 decisions
instructions: Identify 5 decisions (past or upcoming)
For each: Map first-order effects (obvious consequences)
Then: Map second-order effects (consequences of consequences)
Then: Map third-order effects where possible
Identify at least one non-obvious insight per decision
skill_challenges.success_criteria: 5 decision maps with 2-3 levels of effects, insights documented

skill_challenges.name: The Resulting Detective
skill_challenges.description: Analyze 10 past decisions separating process from outcome
instructions: List 10 significant past decisions with known outcomes
For each: Document what you knew at the time (not hindsight)
Categorize into the 4 quadrants: good/bad decision x good/bad outcome
Identify any cases of 'good decision, bad outcome' or 'bad decision, good outcome'
Write analysis of what you learned about decision vs outcome quality
skill_challenges.success_criteria: 10 decisions analyzed, quadrant categorization, written analysis

skill_challenges.name: Kill Criteria Setter
skill_challenges.description: Set and commit to kill criteria for 3 ongoing commitments
instructions: Identify 3 ongoing projects, relationships, or investments
For each: Define specific, measurable kill criteria
Write them down and share with an accountability partner
Set calendar reminders for review dates
If any criteria are met during challenge, follow through on quitting
skill_challenges.success_criteria: 3 kill criteria documented, shared, review dates set
skill_challenges.time_limit: 2 weeks to set, ongoing to evaluate

skill_challenges.name: Steel Man Debater
skill_challenges.description: Steel man 5 positions you disagree with
instructions: Identify 5 opinions or positions you strongly disagree with
For each: Write the strongest possible version of that position
Include evidence that supports it
Explain why smart, reasonable people might hold it
Note if your view changed at all after steel manning
skill_challenges.success_criteria: 5 steel man arguments written, self-reflection on each

skill_challenges.name: First Principles Breaker
skill_challenges.description: Apply first principles thinking to challenge 5 'best practices'
instructions: Identify 5 'best practices' or conventional wisdom in your field/life
For each: Break down to fundamental truths
Question each assumption: Is this actually true? Why do we believe it?
Rebuild from first principles: What would you do starting from scratch?
Document where first principles differs from conventional wisdom
skill_challenges.success_criteria: 5 best practices challenged, first principles alternatives documented

skill_challenges.name: Multi-Model Master
skill_challenges.description: Analyze 3 complex problems through 8+ mental models each
instructions: Identify 3 complex challenges in your life or work
For each: Apply at least 8 different mental models
Document what each model uniquely reveals
Synthesize: What's your integrated understanding?
Create an action plan based on multi-model analysis
skill_challenges.success_criteria: 3 problems with 8+ model analyses each, synthesis and action plans

skill_challenges.name: Decision Process Designer
skill_challenges.description: Design a repeatable decision process for a recurring decision type
instructions: Identify a decision you make repeatedly (hiring, investing, project selection, etc.)
Design a structured process with: information gathering checklist, criteria weighting, bias checks
Document the process formally
Use the process for at least 5 instances
Review and iterate based on results
skill_challenges.success_criteria: Formal process documented, used 5 times, one iteration completed

skill_challenges.name: Thinking Group Founder
skill_challenges.description: Create and run a truth-seeking group for 3 months
instructions: Recruit 3-5 people committed to improving thinking
Establish explicit norms: challenge ideas, seek disconfirming evidence, no ego protection
Meet at least bi-weekly for 3 months
Rotate who presents a decision for group analysis
Document group learnings and improvements
skill_challenges.success_criteria: Group running for 3 months, 6+ meetings, documented improvements

skill_challenges.name: The Metacognition Logger
skill_challenges.description: Keep a metacognition log - thinking about your thinking - for 30 days
instructions: Daily: Log one instance of noticing your own thinking process
Document: What was I thinking? What triggered awareness? What bias/heuristic was operating?
Weekly: Review patterns in your metacognition
End of month: Write analysis of your thinking patterns
skill_challenges.success_criteria: 30 daily entries, 4 weekly reviews, final pattern analysis

skill_challenges.name: Scenario Planner
skill_challenges.description: Create detailed scenarios for 3 major uncertainties in your life
instructions: Identify 3 major uncertainties (career, economy, technology, etc.)
For each: Create 3-4 plausible scenarios with different outcomes
Assign rough probabilities to each scenario
Identify signals that would indicate which scenario is emerging
Create contingency plans for each scenario
skill_challenges.success_criteria: 3 uncertainties with 3-4 scenarios each, signals, and contingency plans

cross_module_connections.description: Critical thinking is foundational to sound financial decisions

specific_links.application: Understanding why selling winners too early and holding losers too long is psychologically driven
Munger's latticework approach is first principles applied to investment analysis
Using base rates of business success rather than optimistic projections

cross_module_connections.description: Better thinking leads to better prioritization and execution

specific_links.application: Every yes is a no to something else - applies to time allocation
Consider consequences of consequences when setting goals
Understanding that we over-attribute others' behavior to character rather than situation
Building the strongest version of the other person's argument before responding
Assuming mistake rather than malice preserves relationships

cross_module_connections.description: Critical thinking skills are high-value career differentiators

specific_links.application: Build career around genuine strengths, not perceived ones
Know when to quit a job or career path

cross_module_connections.description: Understanding cognitive biases helps both in selling and avoiding being manipulated

specific_links.application: Frame offers in terms of what customers lose by not buying

cross_module_connections.description: Clear thinking requires emotional regulation; emotional wisdom requires accurate perception

specific_links.application: Don't make important decisions in strong emotional states
Thinking about thinking is a form of mindfulness

metadata.author: Self-Mastery OS
sources: Thinking, Fast and Slow - Daniel Kahneman
The Great Mental Models - Shane Parrish
Poor Charlie's Almanack - Charlie Munger (reference only)
notes: Charlie Munger content resides in money_masters.json - this module references but does not duplicate
Mental models list is intentionally extensive for comprehensive coverage
Daily insights designed for rotation - use one per day for 18 days
